choices.text: Aqueous humor is primarily produced by the non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary body.
Carbonic anhydrase plays a critical role in aqueous humor formation by facilitating the production of bicarbonate ions.
Sympathetic stimulation increases aqueous humor production by activating alpha-adrenergic receptors.
Aqueous humor flows from the posterior chamber to the anterior chamber via the pupil.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with complaints of gradual vision loss over the past few months. His intraocular pressure (IOP) is measured to be 30 mmHg in both eyes. On gonioscopy, open angles are noted, and no significant optic nerve damage is visible on fundus examination. His family history is significant for primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). Which of the following statements regarding the physiology of aqueous humor production is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Option C). Sympathetic stimulation increases aqueous humor production by activating alpha-adrenergic receptors - Incorrect. Sympathetic stimulation mainly involves beta-adrenergic receptors in the ciliary epithelium, increasing aqueous humor production. Alpha-adrenergic agonists (e.g., apraclonidine) reduce aqueous production.

Option A). Aqueous humor is primarily produced by the non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary body - This is correct. Aqueous humor is formed by the non-pigmented epithelial cells of the ciliary processes, mainly through active secretion and ultrafiltration.

Option B). Carbonic anhydrase plays a critical role in aqueous humor formation by facilitating the production of bicarbonate ions - Correct. Carbonic anhydrase helps catalyze the reaction that forms bicarbonate ions, which drive sodium and water movement, contributing to aqueous humor formation. This is why carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide) are effective in reducing aqueous production.

Option D). Aqueous humor flows from the posterior chamber to the anterior chamber via the pupil - This is correct. The flow of aqueous humor occurs from the posterior chamber (behind the iris) through the pupil into the anterior chamber, maintaining normal intraocular pressure.

Physiology of Aqueous Humor Production in the Eye:

  1. Site of Production:
    • Aqueous humor is produced by the ciliary processes located in the posterior chamber of the eye, primarily by the non-pigmented ciliary epithelium.
  2. Mechanisms Involved:
    1. Aqueous humor is formed by three main mechanisms:
      • Active Secretion (major contributor)
        • Active transport of ions (mainly sodium and bicarbonate) across the ciliary epithelium.
      • Ultrafiltration
        • Plasma from the ciliary body vasculature filters into the ciliary processes due to a pressure gradient.
      • Diffusion
        • Passive diffusion of solutes and water into the posterior chamber along concentration gradients.
  3. Role of Enzymes and Ion Transporters:
    • Carbonic anhydrase: Catalyzes the formation of bicarbonate from carbon dioxide and water, driving the movement of sodium ions and water into the posterior chamber.
    • Sodium-potassium ATPase: Active transport of sodium across the ciliary epithelium aids in the movement of water into the aqueous humor.
    • Bicarbonate and chloride ions: Their secretion facilitates osmotic movement of water.
  4. Adrenergic Regulation:
    • Beta-adrenergic receptors: Stimulation (by catecholamines) increases aqueous humor production.
    • Alpha-adrenergic receptors: Activation decreases aqueous humor production (e.g., alpha-agonists like apraclonidine reduce IOP by this mechanism).
  5. Flow of Aqueous Humor:
    • Aqueous humor flows from the posterior chamber (behind the iris) through the pupil into the anterior chamber of the eye.
  6. Drainage Pathways:
    • Trabecular meshwork and Schlemm's canal: About 85-90% of aqueous humor is drained via this pathway into the venous system.
    • Uveoscleral outflow: Around 10-15% of the aqueous humor is drained through this secondary pathway involving absorption through the ciliary muscle.
  7. Importance in Intraocular Pressure (IOP):
    • Balance between aqueous production and outflow determines IOP. Increased aqueous production or reduced drainage can lead to elevated IOP, commonly seen in glaucoma.

#physiology of aqueous formation #anatomy of angle

Reference: Kanski, Jack J., and Bowling, Brad. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition, Elsevier, 2016, Chapter 10, page number. 180-184.

choices.text: Loss of tight junctions in the corneal epithelium
Deposition of pigment in the cornea
Abnormal collagen fibril arrangement in the stroma

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents with gradually worsening blurry vision in both eyes. On slit-lamp examination, corneal edema with bullous changes in the epithelium is noted. A diagnosis of Fuchs endothelial dystrophy is made. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for the corneal edema and loss of transparency in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Option C). Dysfunction of the endothelial pump: Correct. Fuchs endothelial dystrophy is characterized by the progressive loss of corneal endothelial cells. These cells contain Na+/K+ ATPase pumps that actively remove excess fluid from the stroma, maintaining the cornea's relative dehydration and transparency. When these pumps fail, corneal edema occurs, leading to stromal swelling and light scattering.
  • Option A). Loss of tight junctions in the corneal epithelium: Incorrect. While the corneal epithelium is important for maintaining surface hydration and protecting against infections, loss of tight junctions primarily leads to surface irregularities and epithelial defects, not the stromal edema seen in Fuchs endothelial dystrophy.
  • Option B). Deposition of pigment in the cornea: Incorrect. Pigment deposition in the cornea, as seen in conditions like Kayser-Fleischer rings, causes visible opacities but is unrelated to the loss of transparency caused by corneal edema.
  • Option D). Abnormal collagen fibril arrangement in the stroma: Incorrect. The regular arrangement of collagen fibrils in the stroma is critical for corneal transparency. However, in Fuchs dystrophy, the loss of transparency is primarily due to fluid accumulation, not a disruption in collagen organization.

Key take AWAYS:

  1. Pre-corneal tear film and homogeneity of refractive index throughout the epithelium Avascularity of cornea
  2. Uniform arrangement of stromal lamellar collagen fibrils in a regular lattice
  3. Collagen fibers are highly uniform in diameter (25-35 nm)
  4. The distance between two corneal fibers si also highly uniform (41.5 nm), which is less than half of wavelength of light and thus, helps to maintain transparency by destructive interference.
  5. Relative state of corneal dehydration maintained by Endothelial pumps
  6. Normal Intra ocular pressure (IOP)
  7. Corneal crystallines (Soluble proteins present in stromal keratocytes) reduce backscatter of light,

Clinical Correlations:

  • Corneal Edema: When the endothelial pump fails, the cornea swells with fluid, leading to light scattering and vision loss.
  • Scarring: Injury or infection leading to scar formation in the cornea can disrupt the regular arrangement of collagen fibrils, resulting in opacities and reduced vision.
  • Fuchs Dystrophy: Damage to the corneal endothelium results in progressive edema and loss of corneal transparency.

#physiology of cornea #corneal transparency #corneal edema

Reference: Kanski, Jack J., and Bowling, Brad. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition, Elsevier, 2016, Chapter 2, page number: 23-30.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with excessive tearing and photophobia. On examination, the ophthalmologist notes significant corneal edema and an enlarged globe. The family history reveals that the infant's older sibling having similar complaints at that age. Which of the following genetic factors is most likely implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
• Option A). Mutation in the MYOC gene: Incorrect. The MYOC gene is primarily associated with adult-onset primary open-angle glaucoma, not congenital glaucoma.
  • Option B). Mutation in the CYP1B1 gene: Correct. Mutations in the CYP1B1 gene are the most common cause of primary congenital glaucoma, often leading to abnormalities in the aqueous outflow pathways.
  • Option C). Chromosomal abnormalities involving chromosome 22: Incorrect. While some syndromic forms of glaucoma can be associated with chromosomal abnormalities, it is not a common cause of isolated congenital glaucoma.
  • Option D). Mutation in the PITX2 gene: Incorrect. The PITX2 gene is associated with Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome, which can involve glaucoma, but it is not the most common genetic factor for congenital glaucoma.

#genes in glaucoma #congenital glaucoma #ocular genetics #should know

Reference: Kanski, Jack J., and Bowling, Brad. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition, Elsevier, 2016, page number: 312-318.

choices.text: Kinetic perimetry is primarily used for diagnosing glaucoma.
In static perimetry, stimulus intensity is varied while the stimulus location remains more central with intensity.
Early signs of glaucoma may include generalized constriction of isopters and baring of the blind spot.
For a visual field defect to be classified as glaucoma, it must correspond with optic nerve head abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about perimetry is true?
questions.solution:
• Option A). Kinetic perimetry is primarily used for diagnosing glaucoma: False. Kinetic perimetry is more commonly used for mapping peripheral vision rather than for diagnosing glaucoma specifically.
  • Option B). In static perimetry, stimulus intensity is varied while the stimulus location remains more central with intensity: False. In static perimetry, the stimulus location is fixed while the intensity is adjusted to determine the threshold of vision at that point.
  • Option C). Early signs of glaucoma may include generalized constriction of isopters and baring of the blind spot: False. Baring of the blind spot is a non-specific visual field change and not an early sign of glaucoma; it does not provide significant diagnostic value
  • Option D.) For a visual field defect to be classified as glaucoma, it must correspond with optic nerve head abnormalities: True. Changes in the visual field associated with glaucoma typically coincide with detectable optic nerve head changes, establishing a link between functional loss and structural damage.



Reference: Parson's 22nd edition, section IV, chapter 19, the glaucomas, page number: 287

choices.text: Latanoprost can cause hypertrichosis and increased pigmentation of the iris.
Timolol should be avoided in patients with bronchial asthma due to its potential bronchoconstrictive effects.
Netarsudil is associated with a honeycomb-like corneal edema
Acetazolamide does not require any additional potassium supplementation for electrolyte balance.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding antiglaucoma medications is false?
questions.solution:
1. Latanoprost: True. Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue is known to cause hypertrichosis (increased eyelash growth) and increased pigmentation of the iris due to its action on melanocytes.
  2. Timolol: True. Timolol, a non-selective beta-blocker, can cause bronchoconstriction, making it contraindicated in patients with bronchial asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

  3. Netarsudil: True. Netarsudil is associated with corneal endothelial changes, which can manifest as honeycomb-like edema (corneal endothelial dystrophy), affecting visual clarity.
  4. Acetazolamide: False. Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that can lead to metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia (low potassium levels). As such, potassium supplementation may be required to prevent electrolyte imbalances in some patients

Reference: Kanski, Jack J., and Bowling, Brad. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition, Elsevier, 2016, page number:. 450-460.

#perimetry #investigations for glaucoma #should know

choices.text: Decreased outflow due to trabecular meshwork dysfunction
Mechanical blockage of the anterior chamber angle
Decreased blood flow to the ciliary body

questions.text: A 62-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe unilateral eye pain, headache, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, her right eye is red, and the pupil is mid-dilated and non-reactive to light. Intraocular pressure (IOP) measured at 40 mmHg. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for her condition?
questions.solution:
• A) Increased aqueous humor production: While this may contribute to elevated IOP, it is not the primary mechanism in acute angle-closure glaucoma.
  • B) Decreased outflow due to trabecular meshwork dysfunction: This describes chronic glaucoma rather than acute angle closure.
  • C) Mechanical blockage of the anterior chamber angle: This is the hallmark of acute angle-closure glaucoma. The peripheral iris is pushed forward against the cornea, obstructing the trabecular meshwork and preventing aqueous humor outflow.
  • D) Decreased blood flow to the ciliary body: While this can affect aqueous humor production, it does not explain the acute blockage of the angle.

Acute Angle-Closure Glaucoma

  1. Definition:
    • Acute angle-closure glaucoma (AACG) is a form of glaucoma characterized by a rapid increase in intraocular pressure (IOP) due to the obstruction of aqueous humor outflow from the anterior chamber angle.
  2. Pathophysiology:
    • The condition typically occurs when the peripheral iris is pushed forward, blocking the trabecular meshwork.
    • This obstruction can occur due to anatomical predisposition (e.g., a shallow anterior chamber, thick iris, or a narrow angle).
  3. Precipitating Factors:
    • Sudden dim lighting (pupillary dilation).
    • Emotional stress.
    • Medications (e.g., anticholinergics, sympathomimetics).
    • Hyperopia (farsightedness).
  4. Symptoms:
    • Ocular Pain: Severe, often unilateral.
    • Headache: Can be frontal or generalized.
    • Nausea and Vomiting: Often accompanying the pain.
    • Visual Disturbances: Blurred vision, halos around lights, or sudden vision loss.
    • Red Eye: Conjunctival injection and corneal edema.
  5. Clinical Findings:
    • Pupil: Mid-dilated, non-reactive to light.
    • Cornea: Edematous (swollen), may appear hazy.
    • Intraocular Pressure: Elevated, typically >30 mmHg.
    • Anterior Chamber: Shallow with an obscured angle on gonioscopy.
  6. Diagnosis:
    • Gonioscopy: Visualization of the anterior chamber angle is critical for diagnosis.
    • IOP Measurement: Using tonometry to confirm elevated pressure.
    • Clinical History and Symptoms: Key in making the diagnosis.
  7. Initial Management:
    • Medications to Lower IOP:
      • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide).
      • Topical beta-blockers (e.g., timolol).
      • Alpha agonists (e.g., apraclonidine).
      • Prostaglandin analogs (e.g., latanoprost).
      • Osmotic agents (e.g., mannitol).
    • Pilocarpine: Used after IOP is reduced; helps constrict the pupil and opens the angle.
  8. Definitive Treatment:
    • Laser Peripheral Iridotomy:
      • A small hole is created in the peripheral iris to allow aqueous humor to bypass the obstructed angle.
    • Surgical Iridectomy: In some cases, surgical intervention may be necessary.
  9. Prevention of Recurrence:
    • Laser Peripheral Iridotomy is recommended for all eyes at risk, even if the acute attack is unilateral, as it prevents future episodes.
  10. Long-term Management:
    • Patients with a history of AACG should be monitored for potential development of secondary glaucoma.
    • Regular follow-up visits are essential for IOP monitoring and assessing the health of the optic nerve.
  11. Clinical Relevance:
    • Awareness of acute angle-closure glaucoma is crucial, especially in patients with risk factors (e.g., older age, hyperopia, family history).
    • Prompt recognition and management are vital to prevent irreversible vision loss.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Acute angle-closure glaucoma occurs due to a sudden rise in intraocular pressure when the iris obstructs the drainage angle, leading to symptoms like severe eye pain, nausea, and visual disturbances. Immediate intervention is critical to prevent vision loss.

#antiglaucoma medications #treatment of glaucoma #side effects of anti glaucoma medications #must know

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th Edition, page number: 225.

questions.text: The below image is a treatment for which disorder?
questions.solution:
The image shows Corneal cross linking, C3R procedure used for Keratoconus patients

  • Corneal ectasia
  • Parade trail, central stromal thinning--> apical nipple like protrusion--> irregular astigmatism
  • Typically- patient is never satisfied with glasses, progressive Myopia is seen
  • Signs- oil droplet sign, vogt striae, munson's sign, fleischer ring, rizzuti sign
  • Associated with chronic VKC
  • Complications- acute hydrops, severe corneal thinning, corneal perforation, corneal scarring
  • Treatment- severe scarred cornea will need Corneal transplant. May use Collagen cross linkage to strengthen cornea in early cases

  1. Oil Droplet sign- shows on direct ophthalmoscopy
  2. Vogt striae- On slit lamp examination, vertical stromal stress lines. Disappears on pressure to the globe
  3. Fleischer ring- epithelial iron deposit on the base of the cone
  4. Cone protrusion

  1. Munson's sign- bulging on the lower lid in down gaze
  2. Nipple like cone
  3. Acute hydrops- severe cornea edema
  4. Corneal scarring

Rizzuti sign- conical illumination on the nasal sclera when light is directed on the cornea from the temporal side


#Keratoconus #cornea #treatment of KCN

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 9th ed. Elsevier; 2015. page number: 248-250

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with redness, photophobia, and pain in the right eye. He has a history of similar episodes in the past. Slit-lamp examination reveals an ulcer on the cornea with fluorescein staining. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
• The patient has herpes simplex keratitis (dendritic ulcer), which is treated with topical antiviral agents like acyclovir. Prompt treatment can prevent scarring and vision loss.
  • Etiology:
    • Primarily caused by HSV-1, but HSV-2 can also be involved, particularly in neonatal cases.
    • The virus can remain dormant in the trigeminal ganglion and reactivate due to various triggers such as stress, UV light, fever, or immunosuppression.
  • Symptoms:
    • Redness of the eye.
    • Pain and discomfort.
    • Photophobia (sensitivity to light).
    • Tearing and discharge.
    • Blurred vision.
  • Signs:
    • Dendritic ulcers: Characteristic branching lesions seen with fluorescein staining, indicating epithelial involvement.

    • Stromal keratitis: Involves deeper layers of the cornea and can lead to scarring.
    • Disciform endothelitis: Involvement of the corneal endothelium, presenting as gray-white lesions

    • Corneal neovascularization: May occur in chronic cases.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical diagnosis based on symptoms and characteristic dendritic ulcers observed during slit-lamp examination.
    • PCR testing can confirm the diagnosis in atypical cases.

Management:

  • Antiviral Therapy:
    • Topical antivirals (e.g., acyclovir, ganciclovir) for epithelial keratitis.
    • Oral antivirals (e.g., valacyclovir) may be used for more severe or recurrent cases.
  • Corticosteroids:
    • Topical corticosteroids may be used in combination with antivirals in stromal keratitis to reduce inflammation, but must be administered cautiously due to the risk of worsening the infection.
  • Supportive Care:
    • Lubricants for symptomatic relief.
    • Cold compresses may help with discomfort
  • Incorrect options:
    • Topical corticosteroids: Contraindicated in active herpes simplex keratitis as they can worsen the infection.
    • Oral antibiotics: Not effective against viral infections like herpes simplex.
    • Warm compresses and lubricants: Provide symptomatic relief but do not treat the underlying infection.

#viral keratitis #herpes simplex keratitis #fstain- dendritic ulcer

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th edition. Elsevier; 2015. page number: 200-203.

questions.text: A 45-year-old contact lens wearer presents with a painful red eye, significant tearing, and decreased vision. Slit-lamp examination reveals a white, fluffy corneal infiltrate with surrounding edema. The patient reports a recent history of corneal abrasion while gardening. What is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Correct answer: The clinical presentation is suggestive of fungal keratitis, particularly given the history of trauma while gardening and the appearance of the corneal infiltrate. The initial management involves topical antifungal therapy (e.g., natamycin or voriconazole) to effectively treat the infection.

Fungal keratitis is a significant cause of corneal infection and can lead to vision loss if not promptly diagnosed and treated. It is more common in individuals with a history of corneal trauma, particularly those involving organic materials (e.g., plants, soil).

Key Features:

  1. Etiology:
    • Commonly caused by fungi such as Aspergillus, Fusarium, and Candida
    • Associated with environmental exposure, contact lens use, and ocular trauma.
  2. Symptoms:
    • Pain and discomfort in the affected eye.
    • Redness, tearing, and photophobia.
    • Decreased vision and discharge.
  3. Signs:
    • Characteristic white, fluffy corneal infiltrates with a feathery edge.
    • Surrounding corneal edema and possible hypopyon (pus in the anterior chamber).
  4. Diagnosis:
    • Clinical examination is crucial; however, corneal scraping for microbiological analysis and culture is often necessary for definitive diagnosis.

Management:

  • Early and aggressive treatment with topical antifungals is essential.
  • Oral antifungals may be considered in severe cases or if there is deep corneal involvement.
  • Surgical intervention (e.g., penetrating keratoplasty) may be required for advanced disease or non-responsive cases.
  • Incorrect options:
    • Topical antiviral therapy: Not indicated as the infection is fungal, not viral.
    • Oral antibiotics: Ineffective for fungal infections.
    • Topical corticosteroids: Contraindicated in fungal keratitis as they can exacerbate the infection.

#fungal keratitis #satellite lesions #fungal keratitis treatment

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition, Elsevier; 2015. page number. 258-260.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with progressive vision loss and a history of mood swings. On examination, you note a greenish-brown ring at the corneal margin. The patient also exhibits tremors and hepatic dysfunction. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
• Correct answer: The presence of a Kayser-Fleischer ring is a classic sign of Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder that leads to excessive copper accumulation in the body, affecting the liver and brain. The greenish-brown ring results from copper deposits in the corneal margin.

Kayser-Fleischer ring is a distinctive greenish-brown ring found at the corneal margin, formed by the deposition of copper in the corneal tissue. It is most commonly associated with Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder characterized by impaired copper metabolism.

Key Features:

  1. Etiology:
    • Wilson's disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, leading to impaired biliary excretion of copper and subsequent accumulation in various tissues.
  2. Associated Symptoms:
    • Neurological symptoms (e.g., tremors, dystonia).
    • Psychiatric manifestations (e.g., mood swings, personality changes).
    • Hepatic dysfunction (e.g., liver cirrhosis, acute liver failure).
  3. Diagnosis:
    • Diagnosis is confirmed by measuring serum ceruloplasmin levels, urinary copper excretion, and performing a slit-lamp examination to identify KF rings.
    • Genetic testing may also be conducted for definitive diagnosis.
  4. Management:
    • Treatment involves copper chelators to reduce copper levels.
    • Zinc supplements may also be used to inhibit copper absorption.
    • Liver transplantation may be necessary in advanced cases.

Incorrect options:

  • B. Hemochromatosis: Characterized by iron overload; does not cause KF rings.
  • C. Copper deficiency: Would not present with KF rings; rather, it may cause neurological symptoms without the corneal findings.
  • D. Diabetes mellitus: Typically not associated with KF rings

#wilson's disease #KF ring

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition. Elsevier; 2015. page number: 546-548.

questions.text: A patient came to opd with intense watering, pain and photophobia. She was regular contact lens user in the night. On examination there was an epithelial defect. What is the first line of treatment?
questions.solution:
• Patient presents with overnight use of contact lenses not intended for such use of corneal involvement.
  • Commonest complication with such use is development of corneal abrasion (epithelial defect) which can be potentially complicated by secondary corneal infections.
  • Corneal abrasions are potentialy serious complications and must not be ignored. Such cases need to be carefully evaluated to rule out any corneal infiltrate and ensure no contact lens induced keratitis has set in.

Contact Lens Over-wear Syndrome:

Treatment

  1. Immediately Discontinue contact lens use
  2. Frequent antibiotic eye drops or ointment use (preservative free) - 2 hourly - commonly used are tobramycin, Bacitracin/Polymxyin or newer Fluoroquinolones (Moxifloxacin)
  3. Follow up within 1 day or sooner if symptoms worsen
  4. Topical cycloplegics and Oral NSAID to relieve pain
  5. Patching is usually avoided so as to prevent Serious Pseudomonas infections which can develop overnight chances of which increase with patching
  6. Steroid eye drops are avoided as they can inhibit corneal epithelial repair mechanisms and thereby lead to non healing

Reference: cornea by krachmer & man ,3rd edition, page number:1232

questions.text: whorled keratopathy is seen with use of?
questions.solution:
Option b) amiodarone is class 3 antiarrhythmic used in cardiac arrhytmias , on prolonged use can lead to ocular side effects of whorled keratopathy

Option a) digoxin is a ionotropic drug inhibits Na+K+ ATPase pump , its ocular side effect is yellow vision

Option c) ethambutol is an anti tubercular drug causes ocular side effect of colour blindness(blue green)

Option D) steroids - topical steroid causes glaucoma and systemic steroids causes cataract.

Reference: k d Tripathi 8th edition, antiarrhytmic drug , page number: 456

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a fist fight. He reports pain and swelling around his left eye, as well as difficulty moving his left eye upward. On examination, there is periorbital ecchymosis and a positive "sunken eye" sign. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation is consistent with an orbital floor fracture (also known as a blow out fracture), characterized by:

  • Mechanism: Typically occurs due to blunt trauma to the eye region.
  • Symptoms: Difficulty with upward gaze due to inferior rectus muscle entrapment- restrictive squint , along with periorbital swelling and ecchymosis.
  • "Sunken Eye" Sign: Indicates possible enophthalmos due to displacement of the orbital contents.

Key Points:

  • Orbital Floor Fracture: Commonly involves the maxillary bone and may entrap extraocular muscles.
  • Other Options:
    • Orbital roof fracture: More associated with cranial injury and may not present with eye movement restrictions.
    • Frontal bone fracture: Typically presents with forehead bruising and potential CSF leaks.
    • Zygomatic bone fracture: Can cause midface malalignment but not specifically upward gaze limitation.

#orbital floor fracture #ocular trauma

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition. Elsevier; 2015. page number:. 407-410.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of double vision and drooping of her eyelids. She reports that the eyelid droop worsens as the day progresses and that her double vision becomes more pronounced when she looks to the side. On examination, you note significant ptosis of the right eyelid and horizontal diplopia. What is the most likely underlying condition affecting her ocular muscles?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of fluctuating ptosis and diplopia that worsen with fatigue are characteristic of myasthenia gravis. This autoimmune condition affects the neuromuscular junction, leading to weakness of the ocular muscles.

Key Points:

Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by weakness and rapid fatigue of voluntary muscles. It often affects the ocular muscles, leading to specific visual symptoms.

Ocular Features:

  1. Ptosis:
  2. Diplopia:
  3. Ocular Muscle Weakness:
  4. Variable Symptoms:

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Examination: Observation of ptosis and diplopia during physical examination.
  • Ice Pack Test: Improvement in ptosis after applying an ice pack to the eyelid for a few minutes suggests myasthenia gravis.
  • Electromyography (EMG): Repetitive nerve stimulation tests may reveal decreased muscle response.

Management:

  • Medications: Anticholinesterase agents (e.g., pyridostigmine) to improve neuromuscular transmission.
  • Immunotherapy: Corticosteroids and other immunosuppressants may be used for systemic management.

Surgical Options: Thymectomy may be considered, especially in patients with thymoma or generalized MG.

Other Options:

  • Thyroid eye disease: Often causes proptosis and may not typically show fluctuating symptoms.
  • Oculomotor nerve palsy: Would present with specific eye position changes, including "down and out" position and potential pupil involvement.
  • Multiple sclerosis: Can cause diplopia but would usually present with additional neurological symptoms.

#Myasthenia gravis #ocular signs of MG

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th edition, Elsevier; 2015. page number: 407-410.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of hyperthyroidism presents to the clinic with complaints of bulging eyes, eyelid retraction, and difficulty in closing her eyes completely. On examination, there is noticeable proptosis of both eyes, and she has a stare-like appearance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation is consistent with dysthyroid orbitopathy, often associated with Graves' disease. Key features include:

  • Proptosis (exophthalmos): Bulging of the eyes due to increased volume in the orbit.
  • Eyelid Retraction: The eyelids may appear elevated, contributing to the "stare" appearance

Symptoms:

  • Dalrymple sign - lid retraction - Most common sign - 92% cases - occurs due to increased sympathomimetic tone causing contraction of Müller muscle and due to fibrosis
  • Von graefe sign - lid lag - lower lid moves down slowly on downgaze
  • Kocher's sign - frightened/staring appearance
  • Stellwags sign - reduced blinking frequency
  • Griffith sign - lid lag of lower lid during upagze
  • Enroth sign - edema of eyelid
  • Gifford's sign - difficulty in eversion of upper eyelid
  • Rosenbach sign - tremor of closed eyelids
  • Jellinker sign - abnormal pigmentation of upper eyelid
  • Mobius sign : convergence weakness

Other Options:

  • Orbital cellulitis: Typically presents with pain, redness, and fever, and is an acute condition.
  • Thyroid storm: A life-threatening exacerbation of hyperthyroidism; ocular signs may not be the primary concern.
  • Graves' disease without ocular involvement: While it can occur, this patient clearly shows ocular signs.

#Dysthyroid orbitopathy #orbit

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th edition. Elsevier; 2015. page number: 430-435.
